title: 105_s174
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Timbers Battlefield, Fort Meigs, and Fort Miamis National Historical Site Act". The findings and purposes are outlined in the Act. The 185-acre Fallen Timbers Battlefield was the site of a 1794 battle between General Anthony Wayne and Native American tribes. Fort Meigs was built in 1813 after American troops were defeated at the battle of Frenchtown. British troops attacked Fort Miamis in 1813 without success. Fort Meigs State Memorial is in Perrysburg, Ohio, while Fort Miamis and Fallen Timbers Battlefield are in Maumee, Ohio. The Fallen Timbers Battlefield Monument is a National Historic Landmark. The Fallen Timbers Battlefield, Fort Meigs, and Fort Miamis are all listed as National Historic Landmarks. The purposes of this Act include recognizing and preserving the Fallen Timbers Battlefield site, linking it to Fort Miamis and Fort Meigs, and interpreting United States military history. The Act aims to preserve and interpret United States military history and Native American culture from 1794 to 1813 at the historical site. It also provides assistance to Ohio, political subdivisions, and nonprofit organizations in implementing the Stewardship Plan for preserving historical, cultural, natural, recreational, and scenic resources. Additionally, the Secretary is authorized to offer technical assistance to various entities in Ohio for implementing the Stewardship Plan. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Historical site includes Fallen Timbers Battlefield, Fort Meigs, and Fort Miamis National Historical Site. Management entity refers to Ohio Historical Society, city of Maumee, Maumee Valley Heritage Corridor, city of Toledo, Metropark District of Toledo Area, and entities designated by Ohio Governor. Secretary means Secretary of the Interior. Stewardship Plan is the management plan developed by the management entity. Technical assistance is guidance provided by the Secretary. SEC. 4. Fallen Timbers Battlefield, Fort Meigs, and Fort Miamis National Historical Site. Established in Ohio, the Fallen Timbers Battlefield, Fort Meigs, and Fort Miamis National Historical Site includes various sites such as the Fallen Timbers battlefield, Fort Meigs State Memorial site, and Fort Miamis site. The boundaries are defined, and a map of the historical site will be available for public inspection. The historical site boundaries east of Jerome Road do not include privately owned or municipal properties without consent from the owners. SEC. 5. WITHDRAWAL OF DESIGNATION. The historical site will remain designated unless the Secretary determines it is incompatible with the Act's purposes or there is insufficient progress on the Stewardship Plan. A public hearing must be held before a determination is made, and Congress must be notified before the designation is withdrawn. The historical site designation can be withdrawn 90 legislative days after the Secretary notifies Congress. SEC. 6. Duties and authorities of federal agencies. The Secretary may provide technical assistance for the Stewardship Plan to entities in Ohio upon request, without imposing land use restrictions as a condition. The Secretary may decide on awarding technical assistance to historical sites based on their fulfillment of objectives in the Stewardship Plan. The Secretary can assist in developing the Stewardship Plan and provide information on historical site locations. Other Federal agencies have duties related to historical sites. Any Federal agency conducting activities affecting a historical site must consider the potential impact on the Stewardship Plan and consult with the site's management entity to minimize adverse effects. SEC. 7. NO EFFECT ON LAND USE REGULATION AND PRIVATE PROPERTY. This Act does not change the authority of any government to regulate land use or grant zoning powers to the management entity of a historical site. It also does not interfere with private property rights or local zoning ordinances. SEC. 8. FISHING, TRAPPING, AND HUNTING. SEC. 8. FISHING, TRAPPING, AND HUNTING. The establishment of the historical site does not diminish the State's authority to manage fish and wildlife, including regulating fishing, hunting, and trapping. Additionally, fishing, hunting, or trapping cannot be made a condition for eligibility for assistance under this Act or for receiving any other form of assistance related to the historical site from the Secretary or any other Federal agency.
